abstract.p: S Fred Singer letter on Nov 18 article on climate variations and global warming threat (S)

block.p: Contrary to popular belief, the present climate is quite variable. We are still emerging from the Little Ice Age that started around 1450, following the Medieval Climate Optimum that peaked about 1,000 years ago. And as you point out (Science Times, Nov. 18), warm periods brought prosperity, while colder periods brought poor harvests and starvation.

Contrary to popular belief, the present climate is quite variable. We are still emerging from the Little Ice Age that started around 1450, following the Medieval Climate Optimum that peaked about 1,000 years ago. And as you point out (Science Times, Nov. 18), warm periods brought prosperity, while colder periods brought poor harvests and starvation.

This natural variability makes it difficult to discern any human influence on climate. But ocean core analyses, published by Dr. Lloyd D. Keigwin of the Woods Hole Oceanographic Institution, show temperature changes during the last 3,000 years that are larger and more rapid than any anticipated by the United Nations science advisory panel. The upcoming climate treaty negotiations in Kyoto should take note of these scientific facts.
The writer, a physicist, is president of the Science and Environmental Policy Project.
